description: A staple food crop grown for its edible grain, native to Asia.
A subspecies of rice known for its long-grain, non-sticky texture, commonly grown in tropical regions.
A subspecies of rice typically grown in temperate regions, known for its short-grain and sticky texture.
A subspecies of rice found mainly in Southeast Asia, with characteristics of both indica and japonica rice.
A cereal plant grown for its edible grains, commonly known as corn, native to Central America.
A variety of maize known for its deep indentation at the crown of the kernel, primarily used for animal feed and industrial products.
A variety of maize with a higher sugar content, commonly consumed as a vegetable in its immature form.
A variety of maize known for its hard, glassy kernels, commonly grown for flour production and certain traditional dishes.
A variety of maize that produces waxy starch, used in the production of adhesives, coatings, and other industrial products.
A variety of maize known for its ability to pop when heated, grown specifically for popcorn production.
A wild ancestor of maize, native to Mexico and Central America, known for its small and hard kernels.
A rare variety of maize where each kernel is enclosed in a husk, often used for ornamental purposes.
A drought-resistant cereal crop grown for its grain, used in food, fodder, and biofuel production.
A millet species known for its high nutritional value, often used in the preparation of porridge, bread, and other dishes.
A leguminous crop known for its high protein content, commonly used in Indian cuisine.
A leguminous crop used in the production of sprouts and as a staple food in many Asian countries.
A legume grown for its edible beans, rich in protein, often used in both human and animal feed.
A common legume known for its edible pods and beans, widely consumed in many cuisines around the world.
A leguminous crop known for its edible seeds, often used in soups, stews, and salads.
A leguminous crop grown primarily in dry regions, used for both human consumption and fodder.
A legume commonly grown for its seeds, also known as pigeon pea, used in various culinary dishes.
A leguminous crop grown for its high-protein seeds, widely used in food products like tofu, soy milk, and oil.
A species of yam with a large, bulbous root used in traditional cuisine, known for its medicinal properties.
A tropical plant with edible tubers, also known as malanga, commonly used in Caribbean and African cuisines.
A species of plant cultivated for its starchy tubers, also known as taro, widely used in various cuisines worldwide.
A species of yam known for its large, starchy tubers, commonly grown in Asia, Africa, and the Pacific Islands.
A variety of yam known for its smaller, softer tubers, often grown in Southeast Asia and the Pacific Islands.
A species of yam widely cultivated in West Africa, known for its white-fleshed tubers used in traditional dishes.
A species of root vegetable with sweet-tasting tubers, used in a variety of culinary dishes worldwide.
A species of root vegetable known for its starchy tubers, used to produce tapioca pearls and flour.
A tropical plant known for its medicinal properties, often used in traditional medicine for its active compound, forskolin.
